Context: Appears as an epigraph at the beginning of the book.
Hua's father mentions liking it in a fax; Hua hears "liberation" in the solo while his dad hears skill.
Hua's father calls this cover "marvelous" in a fax.
Hua's father praises this song in a fax.
Became his father's favorite song after arriving in the U.S..
Part of his collection; bought after a professor played the violin solo at a dinner party.
Played so often Hua assumed Michael Jackson was a family friend.
Hua's entry into alternative culture; he mocks a classmate for singing the wrong lyrics.
Hua awaited its release and listened to it on tape, amazed by every song.
Blasted on move-out day; later played leaving Ken's funeral as a "sedative".
Hua introduces Alec to the song; they listen reverently in the dorms.

Album: From the Muddy Banks of the Wishkah
Context: Hua buys this live album and listens while studying with Ken.
An anthem for the group; sung during donut runs. Becomes "unbearable" to Hua after Ken's death.
Hua shows Ken the "Sessions" box set at Amoeba Records.
Plays in Ken's car in San Diego; Hua rolls up the window in embarrassment. Later appears in their movie script.
Plays in Ken's car; prompts a discussion about the music video and The Last Dragon.
Ken drives all over San Diego to find the single; they listen to it before finals.
The single Ken bought specifically to get the B-side "Yellow Ledbetter".
Hua's choice of song to listen to before heading out to finals.
Mentioned in Ken's eulogy as a "long-teased" performance that never happened.
Hua listens to his mentorship students sing along to this in the car.
Hua hears this constantly on the radio; initially dislikes it but grows to understand it.
Another No Limit Records song Hua hears frequently on the radio that summer.
Described as having "heavenly harps"; a song Hua needs during his grief.
Mentioned for its "cooing baby" sample; another song Hua finds comfort in.

Album: Songs in the Key of Life
Context: Jimmy tells a story about sneaking into a studio and seeing Stevie Wonder record this.
Mentioned as a time marker for when Hua visited San Quentin in the spring.
Hua obsessively repeats the lyrics, feeling the song was made for him despite its "corniness".
Hua finds this vinyl record in a store exactly one year after Ken's death.
Hua listens to this while taking ecstasy; the song reminds him of Ken's death.
